summary: This is a videotaped deposition transcript of Juan Alessi taken on September 8, 2009, in the civil cases against Jeffrey Epstein. Alessi, a former employee of Epstein, answers questions about his employment duties, payment of massage therapists, and his observations and actions while working at Epstein's Palm Beach residence. This document is a deposition transcript of a witness (likely a household staff member) being questioned about his employment at Jeffrey Epstein's residence. The testimony details procedures for escorting massage therapists (referred to as 'girls') to upstairs bedrooms, payments, the presence of sex toys, and interactions with Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell. The witness describes his duties, observations, and a falling out with Epstein. This document is a deposition transcript of a former employee of Jeffrey Epstein, discussing his employment conditions, his departure, and subsequent incidents where he took money from Epstein's briefcase. The witness details being questioned about a 2003 police report regarding a burglary at Epstein's Palm Beach home, discrepancies in the number of theft incidents, and denies taking a firearm. The deposition also touches on property purchases and the witness's interactions with law enforcement. This document is a deposition transcript of a witness, John Alessi, being questioned by multiple attorneys regarding his employment with Jeffrey Epstein. The testimony covers Alessi's separation agreement with Epstein, confidentiality provisions, payments received, interactions with investigators, and observations about activities and individuals at Epstein's properties. This document is a transcript excerpt from the deposition of a witness, likely Alfredo 'Fred' Alessi, who worked as a house manager for Jeffrey Epstein. The questioning focuses on his employment period (1992-2002), his relationships with Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, his observations of massage therapists at the residence, and his discovery of sex toys. The deposition is part of a legal proceeding, with objections from attorneys present. This document is a deposition transcript of a witness, John (last name unclear), who worked as a driver and house manager for Jeffrey Epstein. He testifies about the recruitment of massage therapists, the daily activities at Epstein's home, his difficult relationship with Ghislaine Maxwell, and his interactions with law enforcement and attorneys.

persons.name: Juan Alessi
persons.context: Former employee of Jeffrey Epstein who managed household operations, scheduled massages, and cleaned up after massages at Epstein's Palm Beach residence. He is being deposed in civil cases against Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as Mr. Epstein, the witness's former employer. The deposition discusses his Palm Beach home, his briefcase from which money was taken, and his statements to police about theft incidents and a missing handgun.

persons.name: Stuart Mernelstein
persons.context: Attorney representing a group of plaintiffs in the civil cases. He conducts cross-examination of Juan Alessi.

persons.name: Robert J. Critton
persons.context: Attorney representing Jeffrey Epstein. He objects to questions during the deposition, particularly those about Alessi's personal incidents and the relevance of certain testimony.

persons.name: Maria Alessi
persons.context: Wife of Juan Alessi who was also employed by Jeffrey Epstein. Her duties included shopping, getting tickets, running errands, and some cleaning. She was hired after housekeepers left.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Referred to as 'Ms. Maxwell' in the deposition. She sometimes instructed Maria Alessi on tasks like buying items and getting tickets. She is mentioned in the context of household management.

persons.name: Mrs. Epstein
persons.context: Jeffrey Epstein's mother. Maria Alessi was sometimes tasked with bringing food to her or driving her to doctors.

persons.name: Mr. Myrna
persons.context: An attorney that Juan Alessi retained after being contacted by an investigator. He was recommended to Alessi.

persons.name: Mr. English
persons.context: Person who helped Juan Alessi get in touch with attorney Mr. Myrna after Alessi was contacted by an investigator.

persons.name: Sandra W. Townsend
persons.context: The court reporter and notary public who recorded the deposition proceedings.

persons.name: Mr. Langan
persons.context: An attorney who conducted part of the examination of Juan Alessi, asking questions about his employment, payment of massage therapists, and his loyalty to Epstein.

persons.name: John
persons.context: The witness being deposed. He describes his stressful employment under Epstein, his salary, leaving in December 2002, and later admitting to taking money from Epstein's briefcase on two occasions in 2003.

persons.name: Mr. Murrell
persons.context: An attorney the witness was put in contact with, possibly by Epstein's lamplighter. The witness met with him briefly but did not know who paid for his services.

persons.name: Mr. Kerkelstein
persons.context: An attorney (likely for the plaintiffs) conducting the deposition. He asks detailed questions about the massage routines, ages of therapists, and financial arrangements.

persons.name: Mr. Crition
persons.context: An attorney (likely for the defense) who frequently objects to the questioning during the deposition, citing form and harassment.

persons.name: William J. Berger
persons.context: An attorney representing three plaintiffs who conducts cross-examination at the end of the transcript, asking about the witness's departure from employment.

persons.name: Mr. Willits
persons.context: An attorney present who repeatedly objects to the form of questions asked during the deposition.

persons.name: Ms. Maxwell
persons.context: Ghislaine Maxwell, identified as Epstein's girlfriend who became the witness's immediate supervisor after Eva Anderson. She is associated with the management of the household and items found in her closet.

persons.name: Mr. Fetterman
persons.context: An attorney who handled legal matters for the witness, including the registration of a fictitious name and articles of organization for a company. The witness states Epstein had nothing to do with these services.

persons.name: Mr. Berger
persons.context: An attorney questioning the witness, likely representing a plaintiff. Asks detailed questions about the separation agreement, payments, and activities at Epstein's properties.

persons.name: Mr. Critton
persons.context: An attorney representing Jeffrey Epstein, present at the deposition and mentioned as having contacted the witness prior to testify.

persons.name: John Alessi
persons.role: Witness / Former Employee of Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deponent, a former employee of Jeffrey Epstein, describes his role, separation agreement, and observations at Epstein's properties, including seeing young women.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Mentioned as a frequent visitor to Epstein's house. The witness is asked if Dershowitz was present when there were naked women, which he denies.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Mentioned as having been at Epstein's house. The witness is asked if he ever saw Prince Andrew naked, which he denies.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.role: Criminal Defense Attorney for Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as Jeffrey Epstein's criminal defense attorney. The witness states he never talked to him.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: Mentioned as an attorney the witness was asked if he ever talked to. The witness states he did not.

persons.name: Joe Joe
persons.context: Described as the house man in New York, working with his wife Lynn. The witness states he hasn't talked to them in over ten years.

persons.name: Lynn
persons.context: Mentioned as the wife of Joe Joe, who worked with him in New York.

persons.name: Mr. Epstein
persons.context: Jeffrey Epstein, the central figure in the case. The witness worked as his house manager from 1992 to 2002.

persons.name: Mr. Alessi
persons.context: The deponent, who managed Epstein's Palm Beach residence. He is being questioned about his employment, observations, and a prior statement given to the State Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Eva Anderson
persons.context: Previously identified as Mr. Epstein's girlfriend before Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Mr. Mernelatein
persons.context: An attorney present who objects to the form of questions during the deposition.

persons.name: Ms. Ezell
persons.context: An attorney conducting part of the examination, asking detailed questions about massage therapists, visitors, and the witness's statement.

persons.name: Mr. Mager
persons.context: An attorney who previously asked the witness questions about individuals visiting the house.

persons.name: Sarah
persons.context: A young girl, identified as under 18, who visited Epstein's house. The witness states she was the only female visitor he knew to be underage and that she never gave massages.

persons.name: Cindy
persons.context: Another girl who worked at the house handling phone calls to 'these girls' near the end of the witness's employment.

persons.name: Tony
persons.context: Mentioned as someone whose hand was 'Cony' (likely a typo for 'Tony'). The witness knew his first name but not his last name (possibly Santiago). He was at Epstein's house and was asked to move his car.

persons.name: Gaetano
persons.context: Mentioned as having a massage pass and getting a massage about every day at Epstein's home.

persons.name: Martin Nowak
persons.context: Identified as a biologist and frequent visitor to Epstein's home. The witness recalls his name.

persons.name: Murray Gell-Mann
persons.context: Mentioned as a possible guest. The witness is unsure but the name is suggested.

persons.name: Gerald Edelman
persons.context: Mentioned as a possible visitor. The name 'Jerry Edelman' is read.

persons.name: Henry Kissinger
persons.context: Mentioned as a frequent visitor. The witness confirms knowing him.

persons.name: Larry Summers
persons.context: Mentioned as a visitor. The witness recalls the name 'Larry Summers'.

connections.description: Alessi was a full-time employee of Epstein from 1991 until his employment ended. He managed the household, scheduled massages, and performed cleaning duties.
Juan and Maria are married. Maria was also employed by Epstein, hired on Juan's suggestion after previous housekeepers left.
Maxwell, as an associate of Epstein, sometimes gave instructions to Juan's wife, Maria, regarding errands and tasks.
Maria was employed by Epstein for approximately three years, performing shopping, errands, and some cleaning duties.
Critton is the defense attorney objecting to questions posed to Alessi during his deposition to protect Epstein's interests.
Maxwell is mentioned as being involved in the household management, giving instructions to staff, indicating a close working relationship.
Alessi retained attorney Mr. Myrna after being contacted by an investigator regarding the Epstein case.
John was employed by Jeffrey Epstein as household staff, with duties including escorting massage therapists and handling payments.
John worked for Ghislaine Maxwell at Epstein's residence and describes her difficult attitude and her involvement in household operations.
John was put in contact with attorney Mr. Murrell, likely for legal protection, though the nature and payment of the representation are unclear.
Epstein's lamplighter connected John to Murrell, suggesting Epstein or his associates may have been involved in arranging or paying for the legal consultation.
John indicates Ms. Maxwell was a manager who would blame him for household issues during his employment.
Mr. Fetterman provided legal services to John, handling corporate registrations. John paid for these services himself.
John admits to taking money from Epstein's briefcase on two occasions after his employment ended, which Epstein reported as theft to police.
Alessi was an employee of Epstein, responsible for house operations. Their relationship ended with a separation agreement including a confidentiality provision and payment.
Mr. Critton is identified as an attorney representing Jeffrey Epstein, present at the deposition to defend his interests.
Alessi describes Maxwell as making work difficult and being involved in managing lists of contacts (like massage therapists) at the properties.
Dershowitz is described as having been at Epstein's house 'a lot of times,' indicating a social or professional association.
Prince Andrew is mentioned as having been at Epstein's house, indicating a social connection.
Alessi communicated with Critton, Epstein's attorney, prior to the deposition, discussing the need to tell the truth.
Alessi was the full-time house manager for Epstein from 1992 to December 2002, responsible for all aspects of the Palm Beach residence operation.
When Maxwell became Epstein's girlfriend, she became Alessi's immediate supervisor. Alessi describes their relationship as not as good as with Epstein.
Maxwell is identified as Epstein's girlfriend who succeeded Eva Anderson. She took a supervisory role in the household.
Murrell was Alessi's attorney present when Alessi gave a statement to the State Attorney's Office in November 2005.
Sarah, an underage girl, visited Epstein's house on multiple occasions. The witness states the main purpose of her visits was to see Epstein.
John had contact with Mr. Critton's office before and after being subpoenaed, including a meeting at his home to discuss Epstein.
Nowak is described as a frequent visitor to Epstein's home, part of the circle of 'extraordinarily bright people' Epstein surrounded himself with.
Kissinger is identified as a frequent visitor to Epstein's home.

events.title: Juan Alessi starts full-time employment with Epstein
events.description: Juan Alessi began working full-time for Jeffrey Epstein, leaving all other clients and dissolving his own company.

events.title: Juan Alessi starts part-time work for Epstein
events.description: Alessi began working part-time at Jeffrey Epstein's house prior to his full-time employment.

events.title: Deposition of Juan Alessi
events.description: Videotaped deposition of former Epstein employee Juan Alessi taken in West Palm Beach, Florida, as part of civil cases against Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Alessi contacted by police investigator
events.description: After receiving a card from a Palm Beach Police Department investigator, Alessi contacted Epstein and later met with an investigator at a Carrabba's restaurant.

events.title: Alessi's incident of taking money/firearm
events.description: Alessi admits to taking money from Epstein (characterized as 'borrowing') and taking a firearm, entering Epstein's property when not allowed. The matter was settled without police involvement.

events.title: Massage Therapy Routine at Epstein Residence
events.description: The witness describes a routine where he would escort female massage therapists ('girls') to an upstairs bedroom, where Epstein would later join them behind closed doors for approximately an hour.

events.title: Rejection of Older Massage Therapist
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell observed a 60-year-old female massage therapist and instructed John to pay her and send her away, indicating a preference for younger women.

events.title: Witness Leaves Epstein Employment
events.description: The witness (John) left his employment with Epstein due to being sick, tired of the job, and particularly because of Ghislaine Maxwell's difficult attitude.

events.title: Discovery and Cleaning of Sex Toys
events.description: The witness describes finding dildos and vibrators in the residence, which he would clean and return to a basket in Ghislaine Maxwell's closet, noting they were used during massages involving Epstein and Maxwell.

events.title: Witness Leaves Epstein Employment
events.description: The witness (John) states he left his employment with Jeffrey Epstein in December 2002.

events.title: First Reported Theft Incident (Labor Day Weekend)
events.description: According to a police report, Epstein reported the first theft of cash from his briefcase over the Labor Day weekend.

events.title: Second Reported Theft Incident (Mid-September)
events.description: Police report indicates a second theft of cash from Epstein's briefcase on a weekend in mid-September 2003.

events.title: Third Reported Incident / Burglary Report
events.description: Epstein reported a burglary at his Palm Beach home (354 El Brillo Way) on October 4-5, 2003, stating cash was taken from his briefcase and a black Glock handgun was missing.

events.title: Witness Questioned by Police
events.description: The witness states he spoke to the Palm Beach Police Department and gave a statement to an Assistant State Attorney in October 2003 regarding the incidents at Epstein's home.

events.title: Witness's Sworn Statement
events.description: The witness gave a sworn statement to an Assistant State Attorney in 2005, the transcript of which is marked as Exhibit 2 in the deposition.

events.title: Company Incorporation
events.description: The witness and his wife incorporated a company in August 2003, with legal work done by Mr. Fetterman. The witness denies any involvement by Epstein.

events.title: October Incident
events.description: An incident referenced where the witness needed money because he was 'messed up with' something, leading to a later separation agreement.

events.title: Signing of Separation Agreement
events.description: John Alessi and Jeffrey Epstein signed a separation agreement, which included a confidentiality provision and a release. Alessi was paid $50,000 and his wife $20,000.

events.title: Witness's Departure from Employment
events.description: John Alessi left his employment with Jeffrey Epstein after discovering his job was being advertised and following conflicts with Ms. Maxwell.

events.title: Deposition Testimony
events.description: John Alessi gives sworn deposition testimony, questioned by multiple attorneys about his employment with Epstein, the separation agreement, and observations at Epstein's properties.

events.title: Witness Statement to State Attorney
events.description: Mr. Alessi gave a statement to the State Attorney's Office, with his attorney Mr. Murrell present. This statement is referenced as Exhibit 2 in the deposition.

events.title: Start of Employment
events.description: Mr. Alessi began working as the full-time house manager for Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: End of Employment
events.description: Mr. Alessi's employment with Jeffrey Epstein ended in December 2002.

events.title: Referenced Incident
events.description: An unspecified incident from 2001 is referenced by the questioning attorney in relation to the witness's testimony.

events.title: Witness Statement to State Attorney
events.description: The witness gave a statement to the State Attorney's Office (Mr. Berger) regarding his knowledge of activities at Epstein's home.

events.title: Recruitment of Massage Therapists
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell, with John driving, visited numerous spas, massage schools, and parlors from Jupiter to Boca Raton to recruit young women, collecting business cards.

events.title: Daily Massage and Yoga Routines
events.description: Epstein had up to three massages a day, very often. Yoga sessions were held in the pool house, massages upstairs. The witness did not know what happened behind closed doors.

events.title: Meeting with Attorney Critton
events.description: After being subpoenaed, John met with Mr. Critton on Labor Day to discuss his testimony regarding Jeffrey Epstein.

locations: 2139 Palm Beach Lakes Boulevard, West Palm Beach, Florida 33401
354 El Brillo Way, Palm Beach, Florida
Epstein's home (location unspecified, but context suggests Palm Beach area)
Jupiter to Boca Raton (area where spas were visited for recruitment)
keyFacts: Juan Alessi was employed by Jeffrey Epstein from at least 1990 (part-time) and full-time from January 1, 1991, managing his Palm Beach household.
Alessi scheduled massage appointments, paid massage therapists sometimes with checks and sometimes with cash, and cleaned the massage rooms afterward.
Alessi's wife, Maria, was also employed by Epstein for about three years, primarily handling shopping, errands, and some cleaning.
Alessi admitted to taking money and a firearm from Epstein, entering his property unauthorized, but settled the matter privately without police charges.
Alessi was contacted by a Palm Beach Police Department investigator regarding the Epstein case, leading him to retain an attorney.
The witness (John) escorted female massage therapists to an upstairs bedroom where Jeffrey Epstein would receive massages behind closed doors.
Ghislaine Maxwell personally rejected a 60-year-old massage therapist, instructing staff to pay her and send her away.
Sex toys (vibrators, dildos) were kept in a basket in Ghislaine Maxwell's closet and were found used after massage sessions involving Epstein and Maxwell.
The witness was put in contact with an attorney, Mr. Murrell, possibly arranged by Epstein's associates, but did not know who paid for the legal services.
The witness left his employment in 2002 due to illness, job dissatisfaction, and Ghislaine Maxwell's difficult demeanor.
The witness, a former Epstein employee, admitted to taking money from Epstein's briefcase on two occasions in 2003 after his employment ended, totaling $6,200.

A Palm Beach Police Department incident report from October 2003 references three separate theft instances from Epstein's briefcase (Labor Day weekend, mid-September, and October 4-5) and the theft of a black Glock handgun, which the witness denies taking.
The witness describes a highly stressful work environment under Epstein and Ms. Maxwell, with long hours, no holidays, and being blamed for various household issues.
The witness states that after finding a police card at his door in 2003, he called Epstein out of fear, and Epstein told him the police contact had 'nothing to do with that money.'

The witness confirms that Epstein contributed $20,000 towards the purchase of the witness's first property but had no involvement in later property purchases or the witness's corporate registrations handled by attorney Mr. Fetterman.
John Alessi, a former employee of Jeffrey Epstein, entered into a separation agreement with Epstein in January 2003 that included a confidentiality provision and a release.
Alessi was paid $50,000 and his wife $20,000 as part of the separation agreement, following an October 2002 incident where he needed money.
Alessi testified about a list of contacts (including massage therapists) kept at Epstein's properties, which was typed and came from New York, and was maintained by Ms. Maxwell.
Alessi observed 'one or two young ones' at the property in the last year of his employment, estimating one girl was about 16 or 17 years old.
Alessi stated that Alan Dershowitz and Prince Andrew were visitors at Epstein's house but denied seeing them naked or with naked women present.
The witness worked as Jeffrey Epstein's full-time house manager from 1992 to December 2002, responsible for all operations of the Palm Beach residence.

The witness testified that during his 11-year employment, he saw between 100-200 different massage therapists (both men and women) visit the house, but he believed all the women were 18 or older, except for one underage girl named Sarah.
The witness stated he never observed any massage therapist appearing distraught, shocked, scared, upset, crying, or injured after leaving Epstein's residence.

The witness described finding two sex toys/vibrators (one described as a 'dildo' and one as a neck/back massager) in a sink and cleaning them before returning them to a closet in Ghislaine Maxwell's bathroom.

The witness's immediate supervisor changed from Eva Anderson to Ghislaine Maxwell when Maxwell became Epstein's girlfriend, and he described his relationship with Maxwell as not as good as with Epstein.
The witness, John, was Epstein's driver/house manager and describes Ghislaine Maxwell as the primary recruiter of massage therapists, visiting spas with a list he compiled.
Epstein had a routine of up to three massages per day, often, with massage therapists and yoga instructors coming to his home.
The witness confirms knowing several high-profile visitors to Epstein's home, including Martin Nowak, Henry Kissinger, and Larry Summers.
The witness states he never saw anyone forced to come to Epstein's home or dragged in, and the girls appeared normal and smiled after getting paid.

The deposition focuses heavily on clarifying a prior statement about a 'young girl' who was a massage therapist versus a friend who was an opera singer, highlighting the scrutiny of witness testimony.
